bibl.title: Letter from Pedro A. Castillo to Philip Showalter Hench, March 14, 1952

div1.p: Castillo thanks Hench for participating in the Conference on Vitamins and Nutrition in Havana. [See 04420009, 04420012 for English and Spanish versions of Castillo's speech.]

div1.head: Letter from Pedro A. Castillo to Philip Showalter Hench, March 14, 1952
div1.opener:
DR. PEDRO A. CASTILLO
L v 17
VEDADO, HABANA
March 14, 1952
Dr. P.S. Hench, M.D.,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
U.S.A.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I wish to thank you very much for your
kind letter. It was indeed a great pleasure for us to
have you and your colleagues at the meeting on Vitamins
and nutrition held at Habana.

We had the privilege of having here
the most representative members of the United States
medicine, which we knew already through their important
contributions to the medical science.

I am sending you a copy of the few
words of introduction which I read before your paper,
whose original I gave Dr. Spies the same day. A friend
of mine was kind enough to translate it in English.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Dr Pedro A Castillo PAC:jrp
enc.

div1.head: Introduction [English translation] for Philip Showalter Hench's presentation at the Conference on Vitamins and Nutrition, by Pedro A. Castillo, 1952
div1.p:
It is a great privilege for us this morning to have
the opportunity of seeing and hearing one of the outstand-
ing representatives of North American medicine today: Dr.
Philip S. Hench, Professor of Medicine of the University
of Minnesota, Director of Research in the Mayo Clinic and
Chief of the Section of Rheumatic Diseases of that Insti-
tution.

In obedience to one of the rules of this Conference,
I have had to accept the honor of introducing our illustrious
visitor to our assembled colleagues; having accepted the
honor, however, I decline the mission: Dr. Hench needs no
introduction.

He was introduced, not to us but to the entire Universe,
as a man of exceptional merits on a Sunday afternoon, Decem-
ber 10, 1950, when he received from the hands of His Majesty
King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden, the Nobel Prize of Physio-
logy and Medicine, granted by the Royal Caroline Institute
of Medicine and Surgery, together with Edward C. Kendall and
Thaddeus Reichstein, “for their discoveries in connection with
cortico-adrenal hormones; their structure and biological ef-
fects”. This, indeed, is the highest distinction to which
the genius and industry of man in the service of human happi-
ness can aspire.

Davisson, the physicist, has said that “the Nobel prize
winner is transformed overnight from an extremely private ci-
tizen into something like a semi-public institution”, and Ken-
dall adds that if he had received his prize in 1950, with all
-2-
the pomp attendant upon the fiftieth anniversary of the
foundation of the Nobel Prize, he surely would have left
out the semi: the man emerges from the status of a private
unit to that of a public Institution as the whole world
looks on admiringly and applauds.

Any physician anywhere in the world who has followed
the development of medical science in recent years must
necessarily have read and pondered over the works of this
man, to whom we are indebted for a direct contribution to
the study and application of the cortico-adrenal hormones
which have revolutionized endocrine physiology and which
have so helped suffering humanity in the relief and elimi-
nation of pain.

Hench was unquestionably a forerunner of these dis-
coveries; intensely devoted to the study of rheumatoid
arthritis (formerly called chronic infectious arthritis)
and related affections, he pointed out in 1925 that the
fatigue, weakness and hypotension common in these patients
raised the possibility, in addition to the supposed infec-
tious factor, of some metabolic disorder somehow related
to the adrenal glands.

Four years later, in 1929, in observing that rheuma-
toid arthritis patients usually improved when afflicted with
jaundice, he insisted that it was not a fatal and progressive-
ly uncontrollable disease, and he suggested the existence in
such cases of some beneficial hepatic or biliar agent which
for the time being could only be called “antirheumatic subs-
tance X”.

In an article which was published on March 16, 1938,
covering research conducted since 1931, he drew attention
to the improvement caused by pregnancy in various chronic
articular affections, and endeavored to establish some
connection with the hypothetical substance X, which might
be some bisexual esteroid hormone, whose action was not
confined to articular affections but applied as well to
other diseases such as asthma, migraine, psoriasis, etc.

In numerous conversations with Kendall efforts had
been made, without success, to identify the supposed subs-
tance X, and although the latter had isolated the so-called
compound E, now known as Cortisone, from the suprarenal cortex
since 1935, the minimum quantities obtained had not been suf-
ficient for clinical use.

The cooperative research work of many scientists finally
led in 1948 to an accomplishment of formidable scientific
proportions and practical application: the use of powerful
adrenal hormones, directly injected or stimulated by the
pituitary corticotropine.

Now, more than a quarter of a century after having first
advanced his theory about the hypothetical substance X, we
shall listen with admiration and with special interest to
this distinguished investigator, who has labored with such
tenacity and persistence in furtherance of his farsighted
conception.
